reviewText: Life is not a problem to be solved
date: but a reality to be experienced." - Soren Kierkegaard\n\nLast Days of Spring (VN) is a very short
recommended: mostly kinetic visual novel about a bunch of teenagers finishing high school

voteText: it is not the most successful or interesting visual novel
helpfulPercent: but it's heartwarming and carries some basic wisdom for anyone just starting their lives.\n\nOur protagonist is Yuka Kishimoto. She is a high school student in Japan
votesHelpful: who attends a school where her father works as a history teacher. She is an ordinary

column29: and the pressures of expectations. I find the approach of the game towards life

reviewText: I bought this game for iPad a couple of months ago and was pleasantly surprised to find it in the Shopaholic Bundle 3" and am super glad to have it on both devices.\n\nWhen I bought this game I was expecting your typical anime high school plot but boy was I surprised! This turned out to be an incredibly well thought-out and rather beautiful work of art. With a beautiful storyline
date:
enchanting music and unique art style I was swept away into this world and really could see myself in the shoes of each character.

More of a kinetic novel than a visual novel as there are only a few choices sprinkled around but definitely insanely good vale for it's price!

Loved the story so much
recommended: I decided to read it again as it had so many inspiring and heartwarming moments.\n\n10/10"

reviewText: I think i got this game for free during a limited time, Thought it might be worth the read. I couldnt find any enjoyment in it. I've been spoiled by all of the better quality visual novels. The poses and expressions are static, I could really careless about any of their situations. Some of the stock images are pretty but mix that with the messy sketch art style of the characters it really clashes. The Music is alright, a bit loud, with no real way to turn it down in game. so i played with it muted. I finished it within an hour, reading everything. Its just not my cup of tea. 2/10

reviewText: It‚Äôs honestly so bad that I curse the day I bought this VN. I‚Äôve played some bad VNs before, but wow‚Ä¶ Last Days of Spring has some serious issues, the story and characters being the main one; the story was dull, characters were badly developed and forgettable, and your choices through the story barely matter at all. I liked the BGs (the only good thing on this mess) and that‚Äôs it. The art style was decent sometimes, but most sprites were bad (characters were ugly and expressionless, just like empty vessels). BGM was horrible, I had to turn off the computer‚Äôs audio (since you can‚Äôt do that on the own game).\n\n1/10, not worth even for free.

reviewText: Not recommended - unless you get it real cheap or through a bundle (go idle for cards). The full price of 2,99‚Ç¨ is not worth it. The visual novel's setting is, as the steampage states, Japanese 'but using Native English vernacular and vocabulary'. Even though the setting is suppose to be in Japan, the characters and overall setting feel far from it. They've all got Japanese names, but that's about it. You don't get immersed into the story or characters. The conversations in the story feel very forced, robotic and too casual (like how one would converse on social media), which is a big turn-off for me. Lines such as 'Is this the train you normally take home?', 'I have to get off at the next stop but that was a seriously cool conversation we had' and 'How west in Tokyo do you live?' fly by. Then there's the waitress who is suppose to be working, but instead is starting a longass conversation and giving you unwarranted advice you never asked for - heck, you never even told her your problems. All in all, if you're looking for a nice enjoyable visual novel, look elsewhere.

reviewText:
I must warn you that this game can be beaten with 100% completion in thirty minutes to an hour. I only have more playtime for card drops.

---

I tried to give this a fair shot, I really did. But this game is missing even some basic features.

Each character only has one sprite, and the backgrounds are pretty clearly free use backgrounds. This might not be such a huge negative if the art was decent for the characters, but it's really not particularly impressive. Strangely, there is one character who kind of contrasts with the others in terms of art style, and I honestly wonder if she wasn't a pulled asset from a different game idea, because she does not fit in with the other characters at all in terms of appearance. The menu used is the default menu style for the program used to make this game, and while I don't think that's inherently a bad thing, it feels lazily done.

There are also no CGs in this game at all, so I hope you don't want those.

The music is so unnoticeable that I almost forgot to put a section for it in here. Thankfully, it is also inoffensive.

As for the story, oh boy. This game very much goes for the tell
hoursPlayed: boring descriptions about every little nuance about a character
voteText: rather than finding out those nuances yourself through how they behave. Another less-than-pleasant trait this game has is its weird random morality spiels. Like
helpfulPercent: one minute you'll casually be talking to a character about their cooking habits
votesHelpful: then suddenly they'll go on about the job economy. What is that? I practically got whiplash from how fast the topic would change in the story.\n\nThe grammar in the game is questionable at times
votesTotal: to say the least. Because of the grammar
votesFunny: the dialogue does tend to have more issues feeling disjointed than it might normally
commentsCount: which doesn't help its case at all.\n\nThe endings are just bad. They're short and make little sense. I even counted the number of lines in one of the endings. Nine lines long. Do you think that's an appropriate length
column16: even for a short visual novel? No.\n\nThere are many more visual novels out there
column17: and I would argue that there are many free ones that are of higher quality than this. Give them a try instead."

reviewText:
Imagine you‚Äôre a parent of a child who is about to finish high school. Your child isn‚Äôt willing to talk to you about plans after high schools because it so ain‚Äôt cool to talk to parents about serious stuff like that. However, your parental instinct tells you that deep inside your beloved child is worried about the future. You want to help, but you know they will never agree to talk it over, at least not at this age. You notice that your child likes to spend time reading visual novels, so you decide to wrap what you want to say in a visual novel. You do some research about visual novels on the internet and write a script containing everything you want to say (in high school student lingo instead of grown up chatter). You also call in favours from friends to compose some simple music, draw some simple characters, take some pretty photos for the background scenery, and package it all together.

This might be the visual novel that you would make.

It‚Äôs short, the plot could be smoother, you forgot to proofread the script, but it contains the caring message that you want to tell your precious child. That it‚Äôs OK to not immediately know what they want to do despite everyone around them looking like they do. That they have many paths in life to choose from. That they will always have your love and support no matter what.

Then you put it on Steam because there‚Äôs no way your child would read it if you directly handed it over, right?

Disclaimer: I am not affiliated with Sapphire Dragon Productions, the developer, in any way. Just in case my closing comment about putting the VN on Steam made it sound like I am.

reviewText:
A stereotyped romantic VN, with some interesting points during the story and a good character design... but it fails in many basics elements (or, at least, what I expect as minimum in any VN):

- No options menu... so you cannot control the volume/sound, the text speed, the transparency...
- No rewind" mode. You cannot return to  read past messages.
- All the characters have the same name color. Pretty confusing.
- All the characters are always in the same pose and emotion.
- The ending feels "rushed" and abrupt.
- Not very polished: the buttons are not alligned
date: some transitions feel weird...\n- There is a character design for the protagonist (as you can see in the trailer
recommended: the header and the cards) but is not used in any scene of the game... Why?\n\nSo
voteText: I don¬¥t recommend this VN. You can try it at a good sale and low price

reviewText:
==== Review ====Last Days of Spring Visual Novel is a rather poorly made visual novel set during the last week of school before an end of the year festival. The extremely linear story (seemingly interactive but actually kinetic) provides nothing unique that every other anime/manga/VN utilizing pre-summer festivities have not shown before. The characters are bland and described using very basic stereotypes. The intro is also a bit cringe-worthy due to its amnesia tactic for explaining the setting, and the ending(s) are truly anti-climactic. It would be more appropriate to describe the various endings as shallow choices (who do you want to spend the festivities with).

Traditional VN options are not present: skip key, text speed, resolution, etc. Dedicated save/loads are supported however.

==== Score ====Overall, I do not recommend this VN due to the unoriginal storyline and primal UI.

Average
- 5/10

reviewText:
I don't play a lot of visual novels, so I can't really compare it to others.

The background foto's were lovely but it clashed with sketchy and rather forgetable character design.

The story itself didn't reel me in either. The plot is simplistic and that was alright. But the execution of it just fails.
The characters were bland, the dialogue terribly unnatural, and storywise just uninteresting, rushed and badly written.
There just isn't anything that makes me care for the characters, their lives or their future.

I give it props for trying to give a good message, and multiple endings including non-romantic ones. But that's about it.

reviewText:
Very short visual story.

According to the description the story takes place in Tokyo, but besides that and the japanese names there is not much that links to Japan. The story could have been told about high school students living anywhere on the planet where there is a school, exams and a beach with a sunset.

As for the story, it is nothing new. But the writing is ok. Sometimes you get a choice what to do next, but I don't think it has a massive impact on the endings. The ending is very short. You get a warning, that you will make your final decision. And then there are between 1 and 5 sentences and the story is finished.

Took me about 90 minutes with some idle times. Not long enough to get all trading card drops

Overall, get it, if its very cheap or in a bundle.
4/10

reviewText:
Last Days of Spring is a Visual Novel where you play as Yuka Kishimoto during her last week of high school. To be honest, I wasn't expecting much from this game to begin with, and I got exactly that.

The only real good of the game was the character artwork, but even that has some flaws: every character only has one pose, so no matter what you're talking about or doing, they're always standing there smiling at you. For a game whose content is literally only artwork and story this is a cardinal sin. At the very least, every character should have some kind of reaction shot or two to better convey their emotions, especially since there isn't any voice acting.

Otherwise, the story itself was mediocre. While it has the feel-good lesson of follow your dreams"
date: the dialogue feels unnatural at times (especially from Yuka's father)
recommended: and the choices you make throughout the game don't actually affect anything. The only choice that actually changes anything is whether you'll walk to school or ride in the car
hoursPlayed: and the choice at the very end where you're able to pick the person you want to spend the Sunset Festival with. The game even warns you to save so that you can experience all of the endings.\n\nUnfortunately
voteText: the endings themselves are very lacklustre
helpfulPercent: you get a few lines of dialogue either about love or friendship
votesHelpful: and that's it.\n\nIf you want an easy 100% achievements or trading cards
votesTotal: go ahead and buy the game for less than $1. Otherwise

reviewText: Not realy sure how I ended up with this game, but I played it despite not being the target audience. It's about a girl's last week in High School and possibly ending up with someone romantically at the party after graduation. It's a passable story, but the art work is pretty mediocre and you're in the position of being introduced to all these new characters who you've supposedly gone to school with for years, so it all feels a bit rushed. You can confess your feelings to someone or not at the end of the game, but there's really not enough time or substance to the game to feel very emotionally invested in any of it. The actual game time is about an hour, the rest was trading card idling.
